deliberation: Formulaic prophetic introduction. Considered whether 'the word of YHWH came' is purely idiomatic or figurative. It pictures God's communication as an entity that can 'come,' which is a mild personification/metaphor.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
ground: Initiated encounter, directed from sender to recipient
posture: Stresses divine initiative and authority of the message
instances.explanation: God’s communication is portrayed as a concrete entity that ‘comes’ to the prophet, personifying the divine word and metaphorically depicting revelation as spatial movement.

deliberation: The verse uses marital/bridal language ('devotion of your youth,' 'love of your espousals') for Israel’s early covenant fidelity. This is an extended metaphor of Israel as YHWH’s bride following Him through the wilderness.

instances.hebrew_text: חֶ֣סֶד נְעוּרַ֔יִךְ אַהֲבַ֖ת כְּלוּלֹתָ֑יִךְ לֶכְתֵּ֤ךְ אַֽחֲרַי֙ בַּמִּדְבָּ֔ר
instances.english_text: The devotion of your youth, your love as a bride— how you followed Me in the wilderness
vehicle: A young bride devotedly following her husband
ground: Exclusive affection, trust, and willingness to follow into hardship
posture: Nostalgic and approving evaluation of former loyalty
instances.explanation: Israel’s youthful faithfulness is pictured as bridal love and trust, casting the covenant as a marriage in which Israel, like a bride, followed YHWH into the wilderness.

deliberation: The verse treats Israel as consecrated produce ('firstfruits of his harvest'); those who 'eat' Israel are guilty. This yields two related metaphors: Israel as firstfruits, and enemies as eaters of that consecrated produce.

instances.english_text: Israel was holy to GOD, the first fruits of God’s harvest.
vehicle: Holy firstfruits set apart from a harvest
ground: Belonging exclusively to God, inviolable, bringing blessing and danger if misused
posture: Affirms Israel’s privileged and protected status before God
instances.explanation: Israel is portrayed as the consecrated first portion of a harvest, emphasizing sacredness and divine ownership.

instances.english_text: All who ate of it were held guilty
target: Nations that attack or exploit Israel
ground: To consume what belongs to God is a profaning act that incurs guilt
posture: Warns that harming Israel is like sacrilege that attracts judgment
instances.explanation: Foreign powers who harm Israel are metaphorically described as people who ‘eat’ God’s holy firstfruits, a metonymic way of describing conquest as consumption that brings guilt.

deliberation: Address formula 'House of Jacob' / 'families of the House of Israel'. These are metonymies where 'house' stands for descendants or nation. No further imagery.

instances.english_text: O House of Jacob, every clan of the House of Israel
ground: Belonging to a common ancestor, unity as one familial entity
posture: Emphasizes shared ancestry and covenant identity
instances.explanation: ‘House of Jacob/Israel’ uses a family-household term as a metonymy for the entire people descended from Jacob.

deliberation: The verse says they 'went after the hevel (vanity/emptiness)' and 'became vain'. This treats idols/delusions as 'hevel' and speaks of 'going after' and becoming like them—metaphorical and idiomatic.

instances.english_text: and went after delusion
target: Israel’s pursuit of idols and false securities
ground: Pointlessness, insubstantiality, inability to give real benefit
posture: Scornful of idol pursuit as utterly empty
instances.explanation: Idols and false hopes are labeled ‘hevel’ (vanity/breath), and pursuing them is pictured as chasing after emptiness.

instances.english_text: and were deluded (became vain)
target: The moral/spiritual state of the people
ground: They take on the worthless, insubstantial character of what they follow
posture: Highlights the degrading effect of idolatry on the people
instances.explanation: Israel is said to ‘become vanity’ like the emptiness they pursued, a metaphor for moral/spiritual hollowness.

deliberation: Mostly literal recollection of the exodus route. However, 'land of צִיָּה וְצַלְמָוֶת (drought and deep darkness / death-shadow)' heightens the desert image, and 'a land where no man passed/dwelt' is exaggerated for effect.

instances.english_text: in a land of drought and darkness (deep shadow of death)
target: The dangers and hardships of the wilderness journey
vehicle: A realm of deathly darkness and desolation
posture: Magnifies God’s saving power through such a fearful place
instances.explanation: The wilderness is portrayed with the intensified language of ‘drought and death-shadow,’ conveying extremity and danger beyond bare geography.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּאֶ֗רֶץ לֹא־עָ֤בַר בָּהּ֙ אִ֔ישׁ וְלֹא־יָשַׁ֥ב אָדָ֖ם שָֽׁם
instances.english_text: a land nobody had traversed, where no human being had dwelt
target: Sparsity of settlement and travel in the desert region
the population pattern of the wilderness
vehicle: Absolute lack of any human passage or habitation
ground: Extreme remoteness and hostility to settled life
posture: Rhetorically stresses the miraculous nature of Israel’s journey
instances.explanation: The claim that no one ever passed or lived there is an exaggeration to highlight how inhospitable the route was and thus how great God’s guidance was.

deliberation: The verse shifts between literal land and cultic language: 'defiled my land,' 'my inheritance you made an abomination.' Land is treated as a cultic object and 'inheritance' is metonymy for the land/people entrusted by God.

instances.english_text: you came and defiled My land
target: The moral and cultic corruption of the community in the land
vehicle: Ritually defiling a sacred object or place
ground: Sin breeds impurity and makes a holy gift unfit for God’s presence
posture: Depicts their behavior as a desecration of something sacred
instances.explanation: The land given by God is portrayed as a holy object that can be ritually ‘defiled’ by Israel’s conduct, personifying the land as a cultic entity.

instances.english_text: You made My possession (inheritance) abhorrent
target: The people/land allotted by God to Himself
ground: What belongs to someone in a special way and represents their interest and honor
posture: Highlights that they have turned God’s own cherished allotment into something detestable
instances.explanation: ‘My inheritance’ stands metonymically for the people/land that are God’s special property, now treated as abominable.

deliberation: Three key figurative expressions: 'shepherds' for political leaders, 'holders of the Torah' as metonymy for teachers/jurists, and 'went after what profits not' as an idiomatic metaphor for pursuing useless idols.

instances.english_text: And the rulers (shepherds) rebelled against Me
target: Kings and political leaders of Israel/Judah
vehicle: Shepherds who care for a flock
ground: Responsibility to guide, protect, and provide for the people
posture: Criticizes leaders for failing in a pastoral duty toward God’s flock
instances.explanation: Political rulers are metaphorically called ‘shepherds,’ highlighting their duty to care for the people as a flock.

instances.english_text: The guardians (holders) of the Teaching ignored Me
vehicle: holders of a scroll or body of law
ground: Expert custodianship implying knowledge and responsibility
posture: Ironically contrasts their formal role as Torah-keepers with their failure to know God
instances.explanation: ‘Holders of the Torah’ is a metonymic idiom for those entrusted with its teaching and application.

instances.english_text: and followed what can do no good
target: Idols and futile objects of trust
vehicle: Going behind something as a follower
ground: Wholehearted pursuit and loyalty to a guide, though here to useless things
posture: Mocks the leaders for earnestly pursuing what is intrinsically useless
instances.explanation: Israel’s leaders are said to ‘go after’ things that do not profit, an idiomatic metaphor for devoting themselves to worthless idols and alliances.

deliberation: God says, 'I will contend (ariv) with you,' invoking lawsuit language with God as litigant. This is a legal metaphor for covenant prosecution, though phrased in normal forensic terms.

instances.english_text: I will go on accusing/contending with you
target: God’s covenantal response to Israel’s unfaithfulness
vehicle: A human party prosecuting a lawsuit
ground: Presentation of charges, demand for justice, formal dispute resolution
posture: Frames the relationship as a legal case that Israel is losing
instances.explanation: God depicts Himself as a litigant prosecuting Israel in a covenant lawsuit, a legal metaphor that personifies divine judgment in human judicial terms.

deliberation: Instruction to look to Kittim and Kedar is geographic and literal, serving rhetorical comparison but not itself metaphorical. No clear figurative expressions beyond normal rhetoric.

Key phrase: 'My people has exchanged its glory (kevodo) for what does not profit.' 'Glory' functions as a metonymy for God Himself, and the 'exchange' imagery evokes commercial metaphor but is lexical. I treat 'glory' as metonymy.

instances.english_text: But My people has exchanged its glory for what can do no good.
target: The true God whom Israel possesses in covenant
ground: God is the ultimate source of honor and splendor for His people
posture: Highlights the folly of trading the truly glorious God for worthless idols
instances.explanation: ‘Their glory’ is a metonymy for God Himself; the people are said to have exchanged the living God for useless non-gods.

deliberation: The heavens are summoned to react emotionally ('be appalled, shudder, be very desolate'). This clearly personifies the heavens as witnesses in a cosmic courtroom.

instances.hebrew_text: שֹׁ֥מּוּ שָׁמַ֖יִם עַל־זֹ֑את וְשַׂעֲר֛וּ חׇרְב֥וּ מְאֹ֖ד
instances.english_text: Be appalled, O heavens, at this; be horrified, utterly dazed!
vehicle: The heavens reacting in shock like sentient observers
ground: If even inanimate heavens should be stunned, the act is exceedingly shocking
posture: Emphasizes the enormity of Israel’s sin by calling the whole cosmos to react
instances.explanation: Heavens are personified as courtroom witnesses who can ‘be appalled’ and ‘shudder,’ underscoring the cosmic scandal of Israel’s behavior.

deliberation: Two core metaphors: God as 'fount of living waters' and the people’s alternative sources (idols/political trusts) as 'broken cisterns that cannot hold water.' Both are sustained, explicit metaphors.

instances.english_text: They have forsaken Me, the Fount of living waters
target: God’s role as life-giver and sustainer
posture: Presents reliance on God as the only truly life-giving option
instances.explanation: God is metaphorically depicted as a spring of fresh, living water, highlighting His role as the only true source of spiritual life.

instances.hebrew_text: לַחְצֹ֤ב לָהֶם֙ בֹּאר֔וֹת בֹּארֹת֙ נִשְׁבָּרִ֔ים אֲשֶׁ֥ר לֹֽא־יָכִ֖לוּ הַמָּֽיִם
instances.english_text: And hewed out for themselves cisterns, broken cisterns, that cannot even hold water
vehicle: Broken cisterns that cannot retain water
ground: Labor-intensive yet useless, fail at the crucial moment, unable to sustain life
posture: Ridicules the alternative trusts as structurally incapable of giving life
instances.explanation: Israel’s substitutes for God are portrayed as cracked cisterns: costly to make yet incapable of holding the water they are meant to provide.

deliberation: Rhetorical questions about Israel as a slave/born-in-house servant and being for plunder. These are literal socio-legal categories applied rhetorically; no distinct metaphor beyond normal usage.
Foreign invaders are described as 'lions' roaring over Israel. This is a standard predator metaphor for attacking nations.

instances.english_text: Lions have roared over him, have raised their cries.
ground: Ferocity, dominance, terrifying power over a helpless victim
posture: Presents Israel as prey and the invaders as savage predators
instances.explanation: The invading nations are metaphorically portrayed as young lions roaring triumphantly over their prey (Israel).

deliberation: Expression 'they will lay bare your head' (or strike/shave the crown) from Egyptian cities Noph and Tahpanhes is an idiom for humiliation and injury, using the head as focal point.

instances.english_text: will lay bare your head (strike the crown of your head)
target: National disgrace and injury inflicted by Egypt
vehicle: head as the most vulnerable/honored part
posture: Warns that dependence on Egypt will end in shameful wounding
instances.explanation: The Egyptians are said to treat Judah’s ‘crown of the head’ harshly, an idiomatic metaphor for deep humiliation and harm.

deliberation: Highlights self-inflicted harm for forsaking YHWH 'who led you in the way.' The 'way' is both literal exodus path and a standard path metaphor for life/guidance. I treat 'leading in the way' as a guidance metaphor.

instances.english_text: Who led you in the way
target: God’s ongoing moral and providential guidance of Israel
vehicle: Leading someone along a road or path
ground: Showing the right route, protecting from danger, ensuring arrival
posture: Underscores the folly of abandoning a reliable guide
instances.explanation: God’s comprehensive guidance is portrayed as leading Israel along a road, using the path metaphor common for moral and spiritual direction.

deliberation: Going to Egypt/Assyria 'to drink the waters' of their rivers is metaphorical for seeking political help/alliance and sustenance from them.

instances.hebrew_text: מַה־לָּךְ֙ לְדֶ֣רֶךְ מִצְרַ֔יִם לִשְׁתּ֖וֹת מֵ֣י שִׁח֑וֹר וּמַה־לָּךְ֙ לְדֶ֣רֶךְ אַשּׁ֔וּר לִשְׁתּ֖וֹת מֵ֥י נָהָֽר
instances.english_text: What is the good of your going to Egypt to drink the waters of the Nile? And ... to Assyria to drink the waters of the Euphrates?
target: Judah’s search for security through foreign alliances
vehicle: Traveling to drink foreign river water
ground: Seeking life-sustaining resources and security from another source, becoming dependent on it
posture: Derides reliance on foreign powers as misplaced thirst that should be quenched in God
instances.explanation: Pursuing Egyptian and Assyrian help is portrayed as going to drink their river waters, a metaphor for seeking life and security from them.

deliberation: Evil and backsliding are said to 'discipline' and 'reprove' the people—clear personification of abstract moral states as teachers/punishers.

instances.english_text: Let your misfortune (evil) reprove you, let your afflictions (backslidings) rebuke you
vehicle: A disciplinarian or teacher who rebukes a student
ground: Painful experience serves as instruction and proof of wrongdoing
posture: Invites them to read their suffering as moral instruction rather than accident
instances.explanation: Their own evil and apostasies are personified as agents that discipline and rebuke them, framing judgment as instruction.

deliberation: Two strong metaphors: breaking the 'yoke' and tether-cords is a slavery/service metaphor for rejecting God’s rule; and reclining as a whore on every high hill and under every green tree is an adultery/prostitution image for idolatrous worship.

instances.hebrew_text: שָׁבַ֣רְתִּי עֻלֵּ֗ךְ נִתַּ֙קְתִּי֙ מוֹסְרוֹתַ֔יִךְ וַתֹּאמְרִ֖י לֹ֣א אֶעֱב֑וֹר
instances.english_text: long ago you broke your yoke, tore off your yoke-bands, and said, 'I will not serve/transgress'
target: Israel’s refusal of covenant obedience to God
vehicle: An animal or slave throwing off a yoke and bonds
beast of burden/service under a yoke
ground: Casting off imposed service and constraint, seeking autonomy
posture: Depicts their disobedience as deliberate rebellion against rightful, liberating rule
instances.explanation: Israel is likened to a yoked animal or servant that violently throws off its yoke, symbolizing rejection of God’s service.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּ֣י עַֽל־כׇּל־גִּבְעָ֞ה גְּבֹהָ֗ה וְתַ֙חַת֙ כׇּל־עֵ֣ץ רַעֲנָ֔ן אַ֖תְּ צֹעָ֥ה זֹנָֽה
instances.english_text: On every high hill and under every verdant tree, you recline as a whore
target: Israel’s idolatrous worship at high places
vehicle: A prostitute spreading herself in public places
ground: Unfaithful, indiscriminate giving of oneself to many partners
posture: Denounces idolatry as shameless covenant infidelity
instances.explanation: Israel’s participation in pagan worship is portrayed as a woman prostituting herself everywhere, equating idolatry with marital infidelity.

deliberation: Extended vineyard metaphor: Israel planted as a choice vine from true seed, but turned into a degenerate, foreign vine. One coherent metaphor of cultivation gone wrong.

instances.hebrew_text: נְטַעְתִּ֣יךְ שׂוֹרֵ֔ק כֻּלֹּ֖ה זֶ֣רַע אֱמֶ֑ת וְאֵיךְ֙ נֶהְפַּ֣כְתְּ לִ֔י סוּרֵ֖י הַגֶּ֥פֶן נׇכְרִיָּֽה
instances.english_text: I planted you with noble vines, all with choicest seed; alas, I find you changed into a base, an alien vine!
target: The moral and spiritual character of Israel
vehicle: A carefully planted choice vine that degenerates into a wild, foreign species
ground: Initial investment and high quality contrasted with later corruption and foreignness
posture: Expresses shock and disappointment at Israel’s degeneration
instances.explanation: Israel is compared to a choice vine that has inexplicably become a degenerate foreign vine, a metaphor for their moral and religious corruption.

deliberation: Language of washing with natron/lye but guilt remaining 'stained/engraved' before God. This clearly depicts sin as an indelible stain that washing cannot remove.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּ֤י אִם־תְּכַבְּסִי֙ בַּנֶּ֔תֶר וְתַרְבִּי־לָ֖ךְ בֹּרִ֑ית נִכְתָּ֤ם עֲוֺנֵךְ֙ לְפָנַ֔י
instances.english_text: Though you wash with natron and use much lye, your guilt is ingrained before Me
vehicle: A stain that persists despite strong cleansing agents
ground: Sin leaves a deep, visible mark that human efforts cannot erase
posture: Denies the adequacy of superficial or self-devised cleansings
instances.explanation: Guilt is portrayed as an ingrained stain that even caustic cleansers cannot remove, stressing its depth and God’s awareness.

deliberation: After denying defilement, Judah is told to look at her ways, then compared explicitly to a 'lustful she-camel, restlessly running about.' This is a vivid simile of restless, driven desire.

instances.english_text: Like a lustful she-camel, restlessly running about
target: Judah’s frantic pursuit of other gods/lovers
vehicle: A young female camel in heat, twisting her ways
ground: Uncontrolled, erratic movements driven by sexual desire
posture: Strongly shames their behavior as animalistic and uncontrolled
instances.explanation: Judah’s idolatrous pursuits are compared to a lust-driven she-camel running in tangled paths, highlighting frantic, uncontrolled desire.

deliberation: Continues the animal-heat imagery, now describing a 'wild ass used to the desert' sniffing the wind in her passion, none can restrain her. This is a metaphor (without explicit 'like') of unrestrained lustful pursuit.

instances.hebrew_text: פֶּ֣רֶה לִמֻּ֣ד מִדְבָּ֗ר בְּאַוַּ֤ת נַפְשָׁהּ֙ שָׁאֲפָ֣ה ר֔וּחַ תַּאֲנָתָ֖הּ מִ֣י יְשִׁיבֶ֑נָּה
instances.english_text: A wild ass used to the desert, snuffing the wind in her eagerness; whose passion none can restrain
target: Judah’s unrestrained drive for illicit unions (idolatry/alliances)
vehicle: A wild female donkey in heat in the desert, sniffing the wind and unstoppable
ground: Untamed, compulsive, and unrestrainable pursuit of desire
posture: Intensifies the shaming portrayal of Judah’s pursuits as beyond rational control
instances.explanation: Judah’s behavior is depicted as that of a wild ass in heat whose passion cannot be turned back, a metaphor for uncontrollable, degrading desire.

deliberation: Two images: 'withhold your foot from going barefoot and your throat from thirst'—a bodily metaphor/idiom for ceasing the exhausting chase after lovers; and 'I have loved strangers, after them I will go' continues the adultery/lovers metaphor for idols/foreign powers.

instances.english_text: Save your foot from going bare, and your throat from thirst
target: Judah’s strenuous pursuit of illicit alliances/idols
vehicle: A traveler running until barefoot and parched
ground: Costly exertion leading to exhaustion and pain
posture: Pleads for them to stop their self-harming chase
instances.explanation: Their political-spiritual pursuits are pictured as running until the feet are bare and the throat is thirsty, urging them to cease this exhausting, futile course.

instances.english_text: No, I love the strangers, and after them I must go
vehicle: A lover passionately attached to foreign partners and chasing them
ground: Emotionally driven attachment leading to active pursuit, despite warnings
posture: Highlights stubborn, self-confessed love for illegitimate partners
instances.explanation: Judah speaks as an unfaithful lover who insists on loving and pursuing ‘strangers,’ a metaphor for foreign gods or powers.

deliberation: Explicit simile: 'Like the shame of a thief when he is found, so is the shame of the House of Israel.' House is metonymic, but main device is simile equating their embarrassment with that of a caught thief.

instances.hebrew_text: כְּבֹ֤שֶׁת גַּנָּב֙ כִּ֣י יִמָּצֵ֔א כֵּ֥ן הֹבִ֖ישׁוּ בֵּ֣ית יִשְׂרָאֵ֑ל
instances.english_text: Like a thief chagrined when caught, so is the House of Israel chagrined
vehicle: A thief discovered in the act and ashamed
ground: Sudden exposure of wrongdoing producing acute shame
posture: Equates Israel’s situation with obvious criminal guilt
instances.explanation: The nation’s shame is compared to the shame of a thief caught in the act, making their guilt vivid and undeniable.

deliberation: Two central figurative moves: idols of wood/stone treated as progenitors ('you are my father,' 'you gave birth to us'); and Israel 'turning the back and not the face' to God, an idiom/metaphor for rejection.

instances.hebrew_text: אֹמְרִ֨ים לָעֵ֜ץ אָ֣בִי אַ֗תָּה וְלָאֶ֙בֶן֙ אַ֣תְּ יְלִדְתָּ֔נוּ
instances.english_text: They said to wood, 'You are my father,' to stone, 'You gave birth to me'
target: The relationship Israel ascribes to its idols
vehicle: Human parents who beget and give life
ground: Source of existence, identity, and care
posture: Mocks the absurdity of crediting lifeless idols with life-giving roles
instances.explanation: Wood and stone idols are personified and treated as parents, ridiculing Israel’s claim that these lifeless objects generated them.

instances.english_text: While to Me they turned their backs and not their faces
target: Israel’s attitude and stance toward God
vehicle: Turning one’s back instead of one’s face to someone
ground: Refusal of engagement, disrespect, and deliberate avoidance
posture: Depicts their behavior as a willful snubbing of God
instances.explanation: Their spiritual rejection of God is portrayed as literally turning their back rather than their face to Him, an idiom for contemptuous avoidance.

deliberation: States 'your gods have become as many as your towns'—a likely hyperbolic way to stress proliferation of cults; and challenges idols to 'arise and save,' which is ironic since they cannot. I treat the numeric statement as hyperbole.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּ֚י מִסְפַּ֣ר עָרֶ֔יךָ הָי֥וּ אֱלֹהֶ֖יךָ יְהוּדָֽה
instances.english_text: For your gods have become, O Judah, as many as your towns
vehicle: Having a distinct god for every town
ground: Overwhelming proliferation and normalization of idolatry
posture: Highlights the scandalous spread of idolatry everywhere
instances.explanation: The claim that Judah’s gods match the number of its towns is likely hyperbole to emphasize how ubiquitous idolatry has become.

deliberation: Question 'Why do you contend with Me?' reuses lawsuit imagery (rîb) as in v.9, portraying Israel as suing God though they are the guilty party. This is a legal metaphor.

instances.english_text: Why do you call Me to account? (Why do you contend with Me?)
target: Israel’s complaints and disputes against God
vehicle: Bringing a legal case or lawsuit
ground: Formal accusation against a party, demanding justification
posture: Exposes the perversity of the guilty party suing the wronged judge
instances.explanation: Israel’s complaints are portrayed as litigating against God in court, an ironic legal metaphor given their rebellion.

deliberation: Two images: 'your sword has devoured your prophets' personifies the sword as an eater; 'like a ravening lion' is an explicit simile comparing this devouring to a lion’s.

instances.english_text: Your sword has devoured your prophets
target: The killing of prophets by the people or rulers
posture: Accuses them of consuming their own spiritual guides
instances.explanation: The instrument of killing (sword) is personified as a devourer that eats the prophets, highlighting the people’s culpability in their destruction.

instances.english_text: like a ravening lion
target: The nature of the violence against the prophets
ground: Relentless, merciless tearing apart of victims
posture: Intensifies the horror of their violence
instances.explanation: The devouring of the prophets is compared to a destroying lion’s attack, underlining its ferocity.

deliberation: God asks if He has been 'a wilderness' or 'a land of deep gloom' to Israel. These are metaphors depicting God as if He were an inhospitable, dark land, which He denies.

instances.hebrew_text: הֲמִדְבָּ֤ר הָיִ֙יתִי֙ לְיִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל אִ֛ם אֶ֥רֶץ מַאְפֵּ֖לְיָ֑ה
instances.english_text: Have I been like a desert to Israel, or like a land of deep gloom?
vehicle: A desert and a land of deep darkness
ground: Harshness, danger, lack of sustenance and light
posture: Refutes any claim that life with God is harsh or joyless
instances.explanation: God rhetorically denies having been to Israel what a desert or deeply dark land would be to travelers, i.e., a hostile, life-denying environment.

deliberation: Uses analogy: can a maiden/bride forget her ornaments? Yet My people have forgotten Me 'days without number.' Comparison between treasured adornments and God as something they should never forget.

instances.hebrew_text: הֲתִשְׁכַּ֤ח בְּתוּלָה֙ עֶדְיָ֔הּ כַּלָּ֖ה קִשֻּׁרֶ֑יהָ וְעַמִּ֣י שְׁכֵח֔וּנִי יָמִ֖ים אֵ֥ין מִסְפָּֽר
instances.english_text: Can a maiden forget her jewels, a bride her adornments? Yet My people have forgotten Me—days without number.
vehicle: A young woman/bride forgetting her ornaments
ground: One does not forget what is precious and central to one’s identity
posture: Expresses incredulity and grief over their prolonged neglect
instances.explanation: The people’s forgetfulness of God is compared to a bride forgetting her ornaments—something unthinkable—emphasizing how absurd and grievous their neglect is.

deliberation: Two figurative elements: 'How well you prepare/beautify your way to seek love'—path metaphor and love as illicit alliances; and 'you have even taught wicked women your ways'—hyperbole portraying Judah as surpassing even the worst in corruption.

instances.english_text: How skillfully you plan your way to seek out love!
target: Judah’s scheming to secure idolatrous/political liaisons
vehicle: Improving/adorning a path in order to find love
ground: Calculated self-presentation and maneuvering to attract partners
posture: Ironically comments on their expertise in pursuing forbidden loves
instances.explanation: Their political-religious maneuvering is portrayed as artfully beautifying a path to seek lovers, merging path and love metaphors.

instances.english_text: Why, you have even taught the worst of women your ways.
target: The extremity of Judah’s corrupt behavior
vehicle: Teaching evil women how to behave
ground: Going beyond the standard of evil so far as to become a teacher of it
posture: Hyperbolically portrays Judah as a mentor in wickedness
instances.explanation: It is exaggerated that Judah has 'taught the evil women' her ways, to stress that she outdoes even the worst in corrupt practice.

deliberation: States that on Judah’s 'wings/garments' is found the blood of innocent poor. Likely metaphor/metonymy: blood on clothing as visible proof of guilt rather than literal forensic detail, recalling legal imagery of bloody hands/clothes.

instances.hebrew_text: גַּ֤ם בִּכְנָפַ֙יִךְ֙ נִמְצְא֔וּ דַּ֛ם נַפְשׁ֥וֹת אֶבְיוֹנִ֖ים נְקִיִּ֑ים
instances.english_text: Moreover, on your garments is found the lifeblood of the innocent poor
target: Judah’s responsibility for the death of the innocent
vehicle: Bloodstains on the edges of a garment
ground: Guilt that clings visibly and cannot be hidden
posture: Openly accuses them of bloodguilt toward the poor
instances.explanation: The image of blood on the hems of garments serves as a metonymic metaphor for undeniable guilt in oppressing and killing the innocent poor.

deliberation: They say, 'I have been acquitted ... I have not sinned,' but God responds by promising judgment precisely for that claim. This ironic reversal exposes their self-justification; main device is irony.

instances.hebrew_text: וַתֹּֽאמְרִי֙ כִּ֣י נִקֵּ֔יתִי ... עַל־אׇמְרֵ֖ךְ לֹ֥א חָטָֽאתִי
instances.english_text: You say, 'I have been acquitted ... I have not sinned.' Lo, I will bring you to judgment for saying, 'I have not sinned.'
target: claim of innocence vs. real guilt
vehicle: Legal acquittal vs. actual impending judgment
ground: Claiming innocence when guilty invites, rather than avoids, condemnation
posture: Uses irony to unmask self-deception and heighten guilt
instances.explanation: It is ironic that the very assertion 'I have not sinned' becomes the cause for judgment, exposing the falseness of their claimed acquittal.

deliberation: Speaks of Judah 'going about greatly to change your way' and being shamed by Egypt as by Assyria. 'Way' again is conduct/policy metaphor; the change of course pictures shifting alliances as path changes.

instances.english_text: How you cheapen yourself, by changing your course (your way)!
target: Judah’s foreign policy and religious posture
vehicle: Changing one’s road or way repeatedly
ground: Inconstancy, lack of firm direction, opportunistic shifting
posture: Critiques their fickle alliances as morally cheap and disreputable
instances.explanation: Judah’s shifting alliances and loyalties are portrayed as restlessly changing one’s path, a metaphor for unstable and debasing policy.

deliberation: Two figurative elements: leaving 'with your hands on your head'—an idiom for grief/captivity/shame; and 'the LORD has rejected your trusts'—'trusts' as a metonymy for the allies/objects relied on.

instances.english_text: with your hands on your head
target: The experience of defeat, humiliation, and grief in exile
vehicle: Gesture of placing hands on the head
ground: Visible sign of distress, shame, and helplessness
posture: Predicts a state of utter humiliation
instances.explanation: Exiles leaving with hands on their heads is an idiomatic image for grief and shame in defeat.

instances.english_text: For GOD has rejected those you trust
target: The foreign powers/strategies Judah relies on
ground: Named by the function they serve (what is trusted in)
posture: Declares God’s disapproval and nullification of their chosen supports
instances.explanation: The term 'your trusts' stands metonymically for the actual allies or devices they rely upon, which God rejects.
